conclusion: Static equilibrium problem with hemispheres
Analyzing forces on both hemispheres step-by-step
Understanding the setup: two hemispheres A (mass m) and B (mass 2m) are between vertical walls
Hemisphere B is against a smooth wall (no friction)
Hemisphere A has friction with the left wall
The line connecting their centers makes a 30° angle with the horizontal
Need to find the dynamic friction coefficient between hemisphere A and the wall
Hemisphere A is on the left and hemisphere B is on the right, with a 30° angle between their centers and the horizontal
Identify forces on hemisphere A: weight mg downward, normal force N₁ horizontal to the right, friction force f upward, contact force F_AB at 30° above horizontal
Identify forces on hemisphere B: weight 2mg downward, normal force N₂ horizontal to the left, contact force F_BA at 30° below horizontal
Apply static equilibrium for hemisphere A: N₁ = F_AB·cos(30°), f = mg - F_AB·sin(30°)
Apply static equilibrium for hemisphere B: N₂ = F_BA·cos(30°), 2mg = F_BA·sin(30°)
By Newton's Third Law: F_AB = F_BA
Calculate contact force F_AB: F_BA·sin(30°) = 2mg, F_BA = 4mg, so F_AB = 4mg
Calculate normal force N₁ on hemisphere A: N₁ = F_AB·cos(30°) = 2√3·mg
Calculate friction force f on hemisphere A: f = mg - 2mg = -mg, indicating downward direction
Magnitude of friction force is |f| = mg
Find friction coefficient: μ·N₁ = |f|, μ = 1/(2√3)
Simplify friction coefficient: μ = √3/6 ≈ 0.289
Final answer: dynamic friction coefficient between hemisphere A and the left wall is μ = 1/(2√3) = √3/6
